text: And thou shalt go to thy fathers in peace; thou shalt be buried in a good old age.
text_kjv: And thou shalt go to thy fathers in peace; thou shalt be buried in a good old age.
text_niv: You, however, will go to your fathers in peace and be buried at a good old age.
text_esv: As for you, you shall go to your fathers in peace; you shall be buried in a good old age.
text_nlt: (As for you, you will die in peace and be buried at a ripe old age.)
text_msg: But not you; you'll have a long and full life and die a good and peaceful death.
text_nasb: 'As for you, you shall go to your fathers in peace; you will be buried at a good old age.
context: Genesis 15 records God's covenant with Abram, a pivotal moment in salvation history. The verse in question, Genesis 15:15, is part of God's assurance to Abram about his future. To understand its significance, consider the cultural context of ancient Near Eastern societies. Dying 'in peace' was not merely a physical state but a holistic concept encompassing harmony in one's relationships and societal standing. A 'good old age' was considered a blessing, signifying divine favor and a life well-lived, free from debilitating disease and sudden calamity. Burial practices were also crucial. Returning 'to thy fathers' was more than just physical interment; it implied joining one's ancestors in the afterlife, a significant concern for societies emphasizing lineage and ancestral veneration. Being denied a proper burial was a great dishonor, believed to condemn the deceased to unrest and eternal separation from their family. The idea of a 'good' old age contrasts sharply with the perceived dangers of premature death through war, disease, or hardship, all of which were common realities in Abram's time. This assurance would have been profoundly comforting to Abram, who likely worried about leaving his descendants vulnerable and without a clear future. The covenant God was establishing promised not only land and progeny but also personal well-being and a dignified end for Abram himself, solidifying the foundation of the relationship between God and Abram's descendants.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 15:15 speaks volumes about God's character and his commitment to his promises. The phrase "go to thy fathers in peace" points to a reality beyond mere physical death. It suggests a peaceful transition to an afterlife, a concept nascent in the Old Testament but ultimately fulfilled in the New Testament through the promise of eternal life in Christ. While the specifics of the afterlife were not fully revealed at this time, the assurance of 'peace' speaks to a harmonious and blessed state. The promise of being 'buried in a good old age' emphasizes God's blessing on Abram's life and his protection over him. It highlights that God is not only concerned with grand, historical narratives but also with the individual well-being of his followers. This verse stands in contrast to the curses associated with disobedience in other parts of the Old Testament, where premature death and lack of proper burial were seen as punishments for sin. God's covenant with Abram demonstrates a commitment to bless those who are faithful to him. The promise of a 'good old age' is not necessarily a guarantee of long life in every case, but rather a representation of God's provision and favor throughout life, even until its end. It's a testament to God's sovereignty over life and death, and his ability to grant peace and fulfillment even in the face of mortality. It sets the stage for understanding God's continued care and faithfulness to his covenant people throughout generations.
application: In contemporary life, Genesis 15:15 offers profound comfort and practical guidance. While we may not always experience literal 'good old age' due to unforeseen circumstances like illness or accidents, the verse reminds us that God's promise of peace remains constant. It encourages us to cultivate inner peace, knowing that our ultimate destiny is secure in God's hands. Practically, this means striving for reconciliation in our relationships, letting go of grudges, and seeking forgiveness where needed. 'Going to our fathers in peace' implies a life lived in harmony with others and with God. Living a life of integrity and faith, aligning our actions with God's will, can bring about a sense of peace that transcends earthly trials. The promise of being 'buried in a good old age' (even if not literally) speaks to the importance of living a life that honors God and leaves a positive legacy. This includes caring for our physical and mental health, nurturing our relationships, and investing in future generations. It also means actively engaging in our communities and leaving the world a better place than we found it. We are called to be good stewards of the time and resources God has given us, ensuring that our lives have a lasting impact for good. As we age, we can focus on passing down our wisdom and experiences to younger generations, shaping them into faithful followers of Christ. Embracing the aging process with grace and dignity, knowing that our ultimate hope lies beyond this earthly realm, allows us to live each day with purpose and joy. This verse invites us to reflect on our priorities and ensure that we are living lives that are pleasing to God, ultimately leading to a 'peace' that surpasses all understanding.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your promises of peace and blessing in Genesis 15:15. Lord, I pray for a heart that seeks reconciliation and forgiveness, that I may live in peace with those around me. Grant me wisdom to live a life that honors you and leaves a legacy of faith. Help me to embrace the aging process with grace and gratitude, trusting in your sovereignty over my life. Give me strength to face challenges with unwavering faith, knowing that your peace surpasses all understanding. May my life be a testament to your goodness and love, and may I one day 'go to my fathers in peace,' joining you in eternal glory. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: No, this verse is a specific promise to Abram, illustrating God's faithfulness. It doesn't guarantee a long, peaceful life to everyone literally, but symbolizes God's blessing and care, both in this life and the next.
